bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John Whelden, September 8, 1951

div1.p: Hench suggests that Reed's family be invited to New York University's celebration of the centennial of Reed's birth. Hench argues that Wheldon is mistaken as to the year in which Reed received a degree from New York University College of Medicine.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John Whelden, September 8, 1951
div1.opener:
September 8, 1951
Mr. John Whelden
Public Relations Division
New York University - Bellevue Medical Center
477 First Avenue
New York 16, New York
My dear Mr. Whelden:
div1.p:
I have your letter of September 5 concerning the celebration in honor of
Doctor Reed. I wonder if you and Doctor McEwen know that Walter Reed's
son and daughter are living. I wonder if you had thought of having one
of them come for the celebration. His son, Major General Walter Lawrence
Reed, is a distinguished retired Army officer who was formerly Inspector
General of the Army before the last war and during the last war was chairman
of various important boards in the Army. He lives with his wife at
2810 Thirty-Sixth Place N.W., Washington, D.C. He is quite retiring and I
am not sure whether he would accept an invitation. Perhaps he would. He
might like to have an excuse to go to New York. Doctor Reed's daughter,
Mrs. Blossom Reed (Blossom was her father's favorite nickname for her and
she has kept that name; she was married, divorced and now uses the name Reed)
lives at Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania. She is fairly active. The
financial circumstances of the Reeds are just adequate and therefore if you
do invite them I think their expenses should be paid. The General of course
has an adequate pension but the daughter lives on a small income. They are
very nice people.

At the moment I can't think of an appropriate telegram to send to you but
will probably think up one and send it as you have requested.

Incidentally, I personally have all of Walter Reed's diplomas. Do you have
a photograph of his diploma from New York University College of Medicine? I
don't believe it was called that in 1897. You say that he is an aluminus of
New York University College of Medicine, class of '97. Surely this is an error.
Walter Reed received his first degree in medicine July 1, 1869 from the
University of Virginia. In September 1869 he matriculated as a student of
medicine, Bellevue Hospital Medical College. In December 1869, while attending
medical lectures at Bellevue Medical College, he took a competitive examina-
tion for the position of assistant physician, Infants Hospital, Randall's
Island, New York and served in the latter capacity January 1, 1870 to April 7,
1871. Regarding his medical career between April 1871 and February 8, 1875, see
my published letter of February 18, 1949 to Dr. Arthur C. Jacobson in the
Brooklyn Hospital Journal, Volume VII, 1949. Shortly after February 1875,
Reed entered the Army. I don't understand what you can mean by the date 1897.
I don't believe he got an honorary degree from your college. He got one from
Harvard and one from the University of Michigan.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
cc: Dr. McEwen
